name: Nigeria
proverb: A man who sweats profusely is the one who eats hot food.

recipe.title: Boiled Yam with Palm Oil Sauce
steps: Peel and slice the yam into thick rounds, then wash thoroughly.
Place yam slices in a pot, cover with water, and add a pinch of salt.
Boil until yam pieces are soft but not mushy, then drain.
Heat palm oil in a pan until it becomes slightly smoky.
Add sliced onions and peppers, and sautÃ© until fragrant.
Season with stock cube and salt, stirring until combined.
Serve boiled yam hot with palm oil sauce drizzled on top.

name: Ghana
proverb: If you do not travel, you will not know how far the river is.

recipe.title: Jollof Rice
steps: Wash the rice thoroughly and set aside.
Blend tomatoes, bell pepper, onion, and garlic into a smooth paste.
Heat oil in a pot and sautÃ© sliced onions until golden.
Add blended tomato mix, curry, thyme, and stock cubes.
Simmer sauce for 10â€“15 minutes until thick and oil separates.
Stir in the washed rice until coated in sauce.
Pour chicken stock to just cover the rice, add bay leaf, and cover tightly.
Cook on low heat until rice is tender and fluffy.
Serve hot with fried plantains, grilled chicken, or salad.

recipe.title: Ugali with Sukuma Wiki
steps: Boil water in a large saucepan.
Gradually add maize flour while stirring to prevent lumps.
Cook while stirring until the mixture thickens into a stiff dough.
Cover and let steam on low heat for 5 minutes, then set aside.
In a separate pan, heat oil and sautÃ© onions until translucent.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add collard greens and stir-fry until tender but still bright green.
Season with salt and serve hot alongside ugali.

name: Ethiopia
proverb: When the webs of the spider unite, they can trap a lion.

recipe.title: Injera with Doro Wat
steps: Mix teff flour with water and allow to ferment for 2â€“3 days.
Cook thin layers of batter on a skillet to make spongy injera.
Marinate chicken with lemon juice and salt for 30 minutes.
Cook onions slowly in a dry pan until browned.
Add niter kibbeh and berbere spice, stirring well.
Add garlic, ginger, and tomato paste to form a sauce.
Add chicken, coat well, and simmer until tender.
Add boiled eggs to the stew and cook a few minutes longer.
Serve doro wat hot with fresh injera.

name: Egypt
proverb: A man without a donkey is a donkey himself.

recipe.title: Koshari
ingredients: Salt and chili powder to taste
steps: Cook rice, pasta, and lentils separately until tender.
Heat oil in a pan, fry onions until crispy, then set aside.
In another pan, sautÃ© garlic with cumin, then add tomato sauce.
Simmer sauce with chili powder and salt until rich and thick.
Layer rice, pasta, lentils, and chickpeas on a plate.
Top with tomato sauce and crispy fried onions.
Serve hot with extra sauce on the side.

name: South Africa
proverb: Wisdom is like fire. People take it from others.

recipe.title: Bobotie
steps: Preheat oven to 180Â°C (350Â°F).
Fry onions in oil until soft, then add curry powder and turmeric.
Add minced meat, cooking until browned.
Squeeze milk from bread, crumble it, and add to the meat mixture.
Stir in chutney, salt, and pepper.
Transfer mixture into a greased baking dish.
Whisk eggs with milk, then pour over the top of the meat.
Bake for 30â€“40 minutes until golden brown.
Serve hot with yellow rice and chutney.

name: Morocco
proverb: A small house will hold a hundred friends.

recipe.title: Chicken Tagine
steps: Rub chicken with garlic, ginger, turmeric, and cinnamon.
Heat olive oil in a tagine or pot and sautÃ© onions until soft.
Add chicken pieces and brown on all sides.
Add preserved lemons, olives, and enough water to simmer.
Cover and cook slowly until chicken is tender.
Adjust seasoning and garnish with fresh herbs if desired.
Serve hot with couscous or bread.

name: Senegal
proverb: A canoe does not know who is king. When it turns over, everyone gets wet.

recipe.title: Thieboudienne
steps: Season fish with salt and pepper, then set aside.
Heat oil in a large pot, sautÃ© onions and tomatoes.
Add tomato paste and cook into a thick base.
Add vegetables and fish, cover with water, and simmer.
Remove fish once cooked and set aside.
Add rice to the pot, stir, and cook until tender.
Return fish on top of rice before serving.
Serve hot with extra sauce.

name: Tanzania
proverb: Little by little, a little becomes a lot.

recipe.title: Nyama Choma
ingredients: 1kg goat or beef, cut into chunks
steps: Marinate meat with garlic, chili, black pepper, salt, and lemon juice.
Cover and let sit for at least 1 hour.
Preheat grill or barbecue.
Grill meat over medium-high heat, turning occasionally.
Baste with oil during cooking to keep moist.
Cook until meat is smoky, charred, and tender.
Serve hot with kachumbari (tomato-onion salad).
